Cross-Layer Optimization of MIMO-Based Mesh Networks with Gaussian Vector Broadcast Channels

Jia Liu and Y. Thomas Hou The Bradley Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061
Email: {kevinlau, thou}@vt.edu
Abstract

MIMO technology is one of the most significant advances in the past decade to increase channel capacity and has a great potential to improve network capacity for mesh networks. In a MIMO-based mesh network, the links outgoing from each node sharing the common communication spectrum can be modeled as a Gaussian vector broadcast channel. Recently, researchers showed that â€œdirty paper codingâ€ (DPC) is the optimal transmission strategy for Gaussian vector broadcast channels. So far, there has been little study on how this fundamental result will impact the cross-layer design for MIMO-based mesh networks. To fill this gap, we consider the problem of jointly optimizing DPC power allocation in the link layer at each node and multihop/multipath routing in a MIMO-based mesh networks. It turns out that this optimization problem is a very challenging non-convex problem. To address this difficulty, we transform the original problem to an equivalent problem by exploiting the channel duality. For the transformed problem, we develop an efficient solution procedure that integrates Lagrangian dual decomposition method, conjugate gradient projection method based on matrix differential calculus, cutting-plane method, and subgradient method. In our numerical example, it is shown that we can achieve a network performance gain of 34.4%percent34.434.4\% by using DPC.

I Introduction

Since Telatarâ€™s [1] and Foschiniâ€™s [2] pioneering works predicting the potential of high spectral efficiency provided by multiple antenna systems, the last decade has witnessed a soar of research activity on Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) technologies. The benefits of substantial improvements in wireless link capacity at no cost of additional spectrum and power have quickly positioned MIMO as one of the breakthrough technologies in modern wireless communications, rendering it as an enabling technology for next generation wireless networks. However, applying MIMO in wireless mesh networks (WMNs) is not a trivial technical extension. With the increased number of antennas at each node, interference is likely to become stronger if power level at each node, power allocation to each antenna element, and routing are not managed wisely. As a result, cross-layer design is necessary for MIMO-based WMNs.

In a MIMO-based WMN, the set of outgoing links from a node sharing a common communication spectrum can be modeled as a nondegraded Gaussian vector broadcast channel, for which the capacity region is notoriously hard to analyze [3]. In the networking literature, most works considering links sharing a common communication spectrum are concerned with how to allocate frequency sub-bands/time-slots and schedule transmissions to efficiently share the common communication spectrum. As an example, Fig.Â 1(a) shows a simple broadcast channel where there are three uncoordinated users and a single transmitting node. Suppose that messages xğ‘¥x, yğ‘¦y, and zğ‘§z need to be delivered to user 1, user 2, and user 3, respectively. Also, suppose that the received signals subject to ambient noise are x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x}, y^^ğ‘¦\hat{y}, and z^^ğ‘§\hat{z}, and the decoding functions are f1â€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘“1â‹…f_{1}(\cdot), f2â€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘“2â‹…f_{2}(\cdot), and f3â€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘“3â‹…f_{3}(\cdot), respectively. The conventional strategy is to divide a unit time frame into three time slots (or divide a unit band into three sub-bands) Ï„1subscriptğœ1\tau_{1}, Ï„2subscriptğœ2\tau_{2}, and Ï„3subscriptğœ3\tau_{3}, and then find the optimal scheduling for transmissions to users 1, 2 and 3, accordingly. The major benefit of this strategy is that interference can be eliminated.

Although the time or frequency division schemes are simple and effective, they are not necessarily the smartest strategy. In fact, Cover had shown in his classical paper [4] that the transmission scheme jointly encoding all receiversâ€™ information at the transmitter can do strictly better in broadcast channels. However, the capacity achieving transmission signaling scheme for general nondegraded Gaussian vector broadcast channels is very difficult to determine and has become one of the most basic questions in network information theory [3]. Very recently, significant progress has been made in this area. Most notably, Weigarten et. al. finally proved the long-open conjecture that the â€œdirty paper codingâ€ strategy (DPC) [5] is the optimal transmission scheme for Gaussian vector broadcast channels [6] in the sense that the DPC rate region ğ’DPCsubscriptğ’DPC\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{DPC}} of a broadcast channel is equal to the broadcast channelâ€™s capacity region ğ’BCsubscriptğ’BC\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{BC}}, i.e., ğ’BC=ğ’DPCsubscriptğ’BCsubscriptğ’DPC\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{BC}}=\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{DPC}}. However, this fundamental result is still not adequately exposed to the networking research community. So far, how to exploit DPCâ€™s benefits in the cross-layer design for wireless mesh networks has not yet been studied in the literature. The main objective of this study is to fill this gap and to obtain a rigorous and systematic understanding of the impact of applying DPC to the cross-layer optimization for MIMO-based mesh networks.

To begin with, it is beneficial to introduce the basic idea of DPC, which turns out to be very simple. For the same 3-user example, consider the following strategy as shown in Fig.Â 1(b). We first jointly encode the messages for all the users in a certain order and then broadcast the resulting codeword simultaneously. Suppose that we pick user 1 to be encoded first, then followed by user 2, and finally user 3. We choose the codeword xğ‘¥x for user 1 as before. Then, the interference seen by user 2 due to user 1 (denoted by x^2subscript^ğ‘¥2\hat{x}_{2}) is known at the transmitter. So, the transmitter can subtract the interference and encode user 2 as yâ€²=yâˆ’x^2superscriptğ‘¦â€²ğ‘¦subscript^ğ‘¥2y^{\prime}=y-\hat{x}_{2} rather than yğ‘¦y itself. As a result, user 2 does not see any interference from the signal intended for user 1. Likewise, after encoding user 2, the interferences seen by user 3 due to user 1 and 2 (denoted by x^3subscript^ğ‘¥3\hat{x}_{3} and y^3subscript^ğ‘¦3\hat{y}_{3}) are known at the transmitter. Then, the transmitter can subtract the interferences and encode user 3 as zâ€²=zâˆ’x^3âˆ’y^3superscriptğ‘§â€²ğ‘§subscript^ğ‘¥3subscript^ğ‘¦3z^{\prime}=z-\hat{x}_{3}-\hat{y}_{3} rather than zğ‘§z itself. Therefore, user 3 does not see any interferences from the signals intended for user 1 and 2. In the end, the transmitter adds all the codewords together and broadcasts the sum to all users simultaneously. As a result, it is easy to see from Fig.Â 1(b) that the received signal at user 1 is x^+y^1+z^1^ğ‘¥subscript^ğ‘¦1subscript^ğ‘§1\hat{x}+\hat{y}_{1}+\hat{z}_{1}, i.e., user 1 will experience the interference from the signals intended for users 2 and 3; the received signal at user 2 is y^+z^2^ğ‘¦subscript^ğ‘§2\hat{y}+\hat{z}_{2}, i.e., user 2 only experiences the interference from the signal intended for user 3; and finally, the received signal at user 3 is z^^ğ‘§\hat{z}, i.e., user 3 does not experience any interference. This process operates like writing on a dirty paper, hence the name. Although counterintuitive, the capacity region of DPC that allows interference is strictly larger than those of time or frequency division schemes.

After understanding what DPC is, one may ask two very natural and interesting questions:

  1. 1.

    How will the enlarged capacity region at each node due to DPC impact the network performance in the upper layers?

  2. 2.

    Are there any new challenges if DPC is employed in a MIMO-based networking environment?

Notice that, when DPC is employed, the encoding order plays a critical role. For a Kğ¾K-user broadcast channel, there exists K!ğ¾K! permutations. Also, since DPC allows interference among the users, power allocation among different users along with the encoding order has a significant impact on the system performance. As we show later, the DPC link rates in a broadcast channel are non-connvex functions. Thus, even the optimization for a single Kğ¾K-user Gaussian vector broadcast channel is a very challenging combinatorial non-convex problem, not to mention the cross-layer design in a networking environment with multiple broadcast channels.

In this paper, we aim to solve the problem of jointly optimizing DPC per-antenna power allocation at each node in the link layer and multihop/multipath routing in a MIMO-based WMN. Our contributions are three-fold. First, this paper is the first work that studies the impacts of applying DPC to the cross-layer design for MIMO-based WMNs. In our numerical example, it is shown that we can achieve a network performance gain of 34.4%percent34.434.4\% by using DPC in MIMO-based WMNs. Also, since the traditional single-antenna systems can be viewed as a special case of MIMO systems, the findings and results in this paper are also applicable to conventional WMNs with single-antenna. Second, to address the non-convex difficulty, we transform the original problem to an equivalent problem under the dual MIMO multiple access channel (MIMO-MAC) and show that the transformed problem is convex with respect to the input covariance matrices. We simplify the maximum weighted sum rate problem for the dual MIMO-MAC such that enumerating different encoding order is unnecessary, thus paving the way to efficiently solve the link layer subproblem in Lagrangian dual decomposition. Last, for the transformed problem, we develop an efficient solution procedure that integrates Lagrangian dual decomposition method, conjugate gradient projection method based on matrix differential calculus, cutting-plane method, and subgradient method.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In SectionÂ II, we discuss the network model and problem formulation. SectionÂ III discusses how to reformulate the non-connvex original problem by exploiting channel duality. In SectionÂ IV, we introduce the key components for solving the challenging link layer subproblem in the Lagrangian decomposition. Numerical results are provided in SectionÂ V to illustrate the efficacy of our proposed solution procedure and to study the network performance gain by using DPC. SectionÂ VI reviews related work and SectionÂ VII concludes this paper.

II-B Channel Capacity of a MIMO Link

In this section, we first briefly introduce some background of MIMO. We use a matrix ğ‡lâˆˆâ„‚nrÃ—ntsubscriptğ‡ğ‘™superscriptâ„‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡\mathbf{H}_{l}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{r}\times n_{t}} to represent the MIMO channel gain matrix from the transmitting node to the receiving node of link lğ‘™l, where ntsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡n_{t} and nrsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘Ÿn_{r} are the numbers of transmitting and receiving antenna elements of each node, respectively. ğ‡lsubscriptğ‡ğ‘™\mathbf{H}_{l} captures the effect of the scattering environment between the transmitter and the receiver of link lğ‘™l. In an additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel, the received complex base-band signal vector for a MIMO link lğ‘™l with ntsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡n_{t} transmitting antennas and nrsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘Ÿn_{r} receiving antennas is given by

Let matrix ğlsubscriptğğ‘™\mathbf{Q}_{l} represent the covariance matrix of a zero-mean Gaussian input symbol vector ğ±lsubscriptğ±ğ‘™\mathbf{x}_{l} at link lğ‘™l, i.e., ğl=ğ”¼â€‹{ğ±lâ‹…ğ±lâ€ }subscriptğğ‘™ğ”¼â‹…subscriptğ±ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘™â€ \mathbf{Q}_{l}=\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{x}_{l}\cdot\mathbf{x}_{l}^{{\dagger}}\right\}. This implies that ğlsubscriptğğ‘™\mathbf{Q}_{l} is Hermitian and ğlâª°0succeeds-or-equalssubscriptğğ‘™0\mathbf{Q}_{l}\succeq 0. Physically, ğlsubscriptğğ‘™\mathbf{Q}_{l} represents the power allocation in different antenna elements in link lğ‘™lâ€™s transmitter and the correlation between each pair of the transmit and receive antenna elements. Trâ€‹{ğl}Trsubscriptğğ‘™\mathrm{Tr}\{\mathbf{Q}_{l}\} is the total transmission power at the transmitter of link lğ‘™l. The capacity of a MIMO link lğ‘™l in an AWGN channel with a unit bandwidth can be computed as

Rlâ€‹(ğl)=log2â¡|ğˆ+Ïlâ€‹ğ‡lâ€‹ğlâ€‹ğ‡lâ€ |,subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™subscriptğğ‘™subscript2ğˆsubscriptğœŒğ‘™subscriptğ‡ğ‘™subscriptğğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‡ğ‘™â€ \displaystyle R_{l}(\mathbf{Q}_{l})=\log_{2}\left|\mathbf{I}+\rho_{l}\mathbf{H}_{l}\mathbf{Q}_{l}\mathbf{H}_{l}^{{\dagger}}\right|, (7)

It can be seen that different power allocations to the antennas will have different impacts on the link capacity. Therefore, the optimal input covariance matrix ğlâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğğ‘™\mathbf{Q}_{l}^{*} needs to be determined. In a single link environment, the optimal input covariance matrix can be computed by water-filling the total power over the eigenmodes (signaling direction) of the MIMO channel matrix [1]. However, in a networking environment, finding the optimal input covariance matrices is a substantially more challenging task. Determining the optimal input covariance matrices is one of the major goals in our cross-layer optimization.

II-C MIMO-BC Link Layer

A communication system where a single transmitter sends independent information to multiple uncoordinated receivers is referred to as a broadcast channel. If the channel gain of each link in the broadcast channel is a matrix and the noise to each link is a Gaussian random vector, the channel is termed â€œGaussian vector broadcast channelâ€. Fig.Â 2 illustrates a Kğ¾K-user Gaussian vector broadcast channel, where independent messages W1,â€¦,WKsubscriptğ‘Š1â€¦subscriptğ‘Šğ¾W_{1},\ldots,W_{K} are jointly encoded by the transmitter, and the receivers are trying to decode W1,â€¦,WKsubscriptğ‘Š1â€¦subscriptğ‘Šğ¾W_{1},\ldots,W_{K}, respectively. A (n,2nâ€‹R1,â€¦,2nâ€‹RK)Bâ€‹Csubscriptğ‘›superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…1â€¦superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…ğ¾ğµğ¶(n,2^{nR_{1}},\ldots,2^{nR_{K}})_{BC} codebook for a broadcast channel consists of an encoding function ğ±nâ€‹(W1,â€¦,WK)superscriptğ±ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Š1â€¦subscriptğ‘Šğ¾\mathbf{x}^{n}(W_{1},\ldots,W_{K}) where Wiâˆˆ{1,â€¦,2nâ€‹Ri}subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–1â€¦superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–W_{i}\in\{1,\ldots,2^{nR_{i}}\}, i=1,2,â€¦,Kğ‘–12â€¦ğ¾i=1,2,\ldots,K. The decoding function of receiver iğ‘–i is W^iâ€‹(ğ²in)subscript^ğ‘Šğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘–ğ‘›\hat{W}_{i}(\mathbf{y}_{i}^{n}) . An error occurs when W^iâ‰ Wisubscript^ğ‘Šğ‘–subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–\hat{W}_{i}\neq W_{i}. II-D Problem Formulation

In this paper, we aim to solve the problem of jointly optimizing DPC per-antenna power allocation at each node in the link layer and multihop/multipath routing in a MIMO-based WMN. Suppose that each node in the network has been assigned a certain (possibly reused) frequency band that will not cause interference to any other node in the network. Also, the incoming and outgoing bands of each node are non-overlapping such that each node can transmit and receive simultaneously. How to perform channel assignments is a huge research topic on its own merits, and there are a vast amount of literature that discuss channel assignment problems. Thus, in this paper, we focus on how to jointly optimize routing in the network layer and the DPC power allocation in the link layer for each node when a channel assignment is given. We adopt the well-known proportional fairness utility function, i.e., lnâ¡(sf)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“\ln(s_{f}) for flow fğ‘“f. In CRPA, we wish to maximize the sum of all utility functions. In the link layer, since the total transmit power of each node is subject to a maximum power constraint, we have âˆ‘lâˆˆğ’ªâ€‹(n)Trâ€‹{ğšªl}â‰¤Pmax(n)subscriptğ‘™ğ’ªğ‘›Trsubscriptğšªğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›\sum_{l\in\mathcal{O}\left(n\right)}\mathrm{Tr}\{\mathbf{\Gamma}_{l}\}\leq P_{\max}^{(n)}, 1â‰¤nâ‰¤N1ğ‘›ğ‘1\leq n\leq N, where Pmax(n)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{\max}^{(n)} represents the maximum transmit power of node nğ‘›n. Since the total amount of flow in each link lğ‘™l cannot exceed its capacity limit, we must have âˆ‘f=1Ftl(f)â‰¤Rlâ€‹(ğšª)superscriptsubscriptğ‘“1ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™ğ‘“subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™ğšª\sum_{f=1}^{F}t_{l}^{(f)}\leq R_{l}(\mathbf{\Gamma}), 1â‰¤lâ‰¤L1ğ‘™ğ¿1\leq l\leq L. This can be further compactly written using matrix-vector notations as âŸ¨ğŸ,ğ“Tâ€‹ğlâŸ©â‰¤Rlâ€‹(ğšª)1superscriptğ“ğ‘‡subscriptğğ‘™subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™ğšª\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\leq R_{l}(\mathbf{\Gamma}), 1â‰¤lâ‰¤L1ğ‘™ğ¿1\leq l\leq L. Coupling the network layer model in SectionÂ II-A and MIMO-BC link layer model in SectionÂ II-C, we have the problem formulation for CRPA as in (9).

III Reformulation of CRPA

As we pointed out earlier, the DPC rate equation in (8) is neither a concave nor a convex function of the input covariance matrices. As a result, the cross-layer optimization problem in (9) is a non-convex optimization problem, which is very hard to solve numerically, let alone analytically. However, in the following, we will show that (9) can be reformulated as an equivalent convex optimization problem by projecting all the MIMO-BC channels onto their dual MIMO multiple-access channels (MIMO-MAC). We first provide some background of Gaussian vector multiple access channels and the channel duality between MIMO-BC and MIMO-MAC.

III-A MIMO-MAC Channel Model

A communication system where multiple uncoordinated transmitters send independent information to a single receiver is referred to as a multiple access channel. If the channel gain of each link in the multiple access channel is a matrix and the noise is a Gaussian random vector, the channel is termed â€œGaussian vector multiple access channelâ€. Fig.Â 3 illustrates a Kğ¾K-user Gaussian vector multiple access channel, where independent messages W1,â€¦,WKsubscriptğ‘Š1â€¦subscriptğ‘Šğ¾W_{1},\ldots,W_{K}, are encoded by transmitters 1 to Kğ¾K, respectively, and the receiver is trying to decode W1,â€¦,WKsubscriptğ‘Š1â€¦subscriptğ‘Šğ¾W_{1},\ldots,W_{K}. A (n,2nâ€‹R1,â€¦,2nâ€‹RK)MACsubscriptğ‘›superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…1â€¦superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…ğ¾MAC(n,2^{nR_{1}},\ldots,2^{nR_{K}})_{\mathrm{MAC}} codebook for a multiple access channel consists of encoding functions ğ±1nâ€‹(W1),â€¦,ğ±Knâ€‹(WK)superscriptsubscriptğ±1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Š1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ¾ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Šğ¾\mathbf{x}_{1}^{n}(W_{1}),\ldots,\mathbf{x}_{K}^{n}(W_{K}) where Wiâˆˆ{1,â€¦,2nâ€‹Ri}subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–1â€¦superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–W_{i}\in\{1,\ldots,2^{nR_{i}}\}, i=1,2,â€¦,Kğ‘–12â€¦ğ¾i=1,2,\ldots,K. The decoding functions at the receiver are W^iâ€‹(ğ²in)subscript^ğ‘Šğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘–ğ‘›\hat{W}_{i}(\mathbf{y}_{i}^{n}), i=1,2,â€¦,Kğ‘–12â€¦ğ¾i=1,2,\ldots,K. An error occurs when W^iâ‰ Wisubscript^ğ‘Šğ‘–subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–\hat{W}_{i}\neq W_{i}. A rate vector ğ‘=[R1,â€¦,RK]Tğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘…1â€¦subscriptğ‘…ğ¾ğ‘‡\mathbf{R}=[R_{1},\ldots,R_{K}]^{T} is said to be achievable if there exists a sequence of (n,2nâ€‹R1,â€¦,2nâ€‹RK)MACsubscriptğ‘›superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…1â€¦superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…ğ¾MAC(n,2^{nR_{1}},\ldots,2^{nR_{K}})_{\mathrm{MAC}} codebooks for which the average probability of error Peâ†’0â†’subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’0P_{e}\rightarrow 0 as the code length nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\infty. The capacity region of a multiple access channel, denoted by ğ’MACsubscriptğ’MAC\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{MAC}} is defined as the union of all achievable rate vectors [3]. We call the Gaussian vector multiple access channel in the MIMO case as MIMO-MAC throughout the rest of this paper.

III-B Duality between MIMO-BC and MIMO-MAC

The dual MIMO-MAC of a MIMO-BC can be constructed by changing the receivers in the MIMO-BC into transmitters and changing the transmitter in the MIMO-BC into the receiver. The channel gain matrices in dual MIMO-MAC are the conjugate transpose of the channel gain matrices in MIMO-BC. The maximum sum power in the dual MIMO-MAC is the same maximum power level as in MIMO-BC. The relationship between a MIMO-BC and its dual MIMO-MAC is illustrated in Fig.Â 4. Similar to MIMO-BC, We denote the capacity region of the dual MIMO-MAC as ğ’MACâ€‹(P,ğ‡â€ )subscriptğ’MACğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‡â€ \mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{MAC}}(P,\mathbf{H}^{{\dagger}}).

The following Lemma states the relationship between the capacity regions of a MIMO-BC and its dual MIMO-MAC.

Lemma 1

The DPC region of a MIMO-BC channel with maximum power constraint Pğ‘ƒP is equal to the capacity region of the dual MIMO MAC with sum power constraint Pğ‘ƒP

ğ’DPCâ€‹(P,ğ‡)=ğ’MACâ€‹(P,ğ‡â€ ).subscriptğ’DPCğ‘ƒğ‡subscriptğ’MACğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‡â€ \mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{DPC}}(P,\mathbf{H})=\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{MAC}}(P,\mathbf{H}^{{\dagger}}).
Proof:

The proof of this theorem can be arrived in various ways [8, 9, 10]. The most straightforward approach is to show that any MIMO-BC achievable rate vector is also achievable in its dual MIMO-MAC and vice versa. The MAC-to-BC and BC-to-MAC mappings can be found in [8]. It is also shown in [8] that any rate vector in a MIMO-BC with a particular encoding order can be achieved in its dual MIMO-MAC with the reversed successive decoding order. âˆ

III-D Maximum Weighted Sum Rate Problem of the Dual MIMO-MAC

Now, we consider the maximum weighted sum rate problem of the dual MIMO-MAC. We simplify this problem such that we do not have to enumerate all possible successive decoding order in the dual MIMO-MAC, thus paving the way to efficiently solve the link layer subproblem we discuss in SectionÂ IV.

IV Solution Procedure

Since CRPA-E is a convex programming problem, we can solve CRPA-E exactly by solving its Lagrangian dual problem. Introducing Lagrangian multipliers uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} to the link capacity coupling constraints âŸ¨ğŸ,ğ“Tâ€‹ğlâŸ©â‰¤Rlâ€‹(ğ)1superscriptğ“ğ‘‡subscriptğğ‘™subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™ğ\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\leq R_{l}(\mathbf{Q}), Hence, we can write the Lagrangian as

where

The CRPA-E Lagrangian dual problem can thus be written as the following master dual problem:

It is seen that Î˜link(n)â€‹(ğ®(n))â‰œmaxâ€‹âˆ‘lâˆˆğ’ªâ€‹(n)ulâ€‹Rlâ€‹(ğ)â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptÎ˜linkğ‘›superscriptğ®ğ‘›subscriptğ‘™ğ’ªğ‘›subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™ğ\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}^{(n)})\triangleq\max\sum_{l\in\mathcal{O}\left(n\right)}u_{l}R_{l}(\mathbf{Q}) is a maximum weighted sum rate problem of the dual MIMO-MAC for some given dual variables ğ®(n)superscriptğ®ğ‘›\mathbf{u}^{(n)} as weights. Maximizeâˆ‘i=1K(uÏ€â€‹(i)âˆ’uÏ€â€‹(iâˆ’1))Ã—logâ¡|ğˆ+âˆ‘j=iKÏÏ€â€‹(j)â€‹ğ‡Ï€â€‹(j)â€ â€‹ğÏ€â€‹(j)â€‹ğ‡Ï€â€‹(j)|subject toâˆ‘i=1KTrâ€‹(ği)â‰¤Pmax(n)ğiâª°0,i=1,â€¦,K.\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Maximize}&\!\!\!\sum_{i=1}^{K}(u_{\pi(i)}-u_{\pi(i-1)})\times\\ &\!\!\!\log\left|\mathbf{I}+\sum_{j=i}^{K}\rho_{\pi(j)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(j)}^{{\dagger}}\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(j)}\right|\\ \mbox{subject to}&\!\!\!\sum_{i=1}^{K}\mathrm{Tr}(\mathbf{Q}_{i})\leq P_{\max}^{(n)}\\ &\!\!\!\mathbf{Q}_{i}\succeq 0,\,\,i=1,\ldots,K.\end{array} (28)

Note that in the network layer subproblem Î˜netâ€‹(ğ®)subscriptÎ˜netğ®\Theta_{\mathrm{net}}(\mathbf{u}), the objective function is concave and all constraints are affine. Therefore, Î˜netâ€‹(ğ®)subscriptÎ˜netğ®\Theta_{\mathrm{net}}(\mathbf{u}) is readily solvable by many polynomial time convex programming methods. However, even though Î˜link(n)â€‹(ğ®(n))superscriptsubscriptÎ˜linkğ‘›superscriptğ®ğ‘›\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}^{(n)}) is also a convex problem, generic convex programming methods are not efficient because the structures of its objective function and constraints are very complex. In the following subsections, we will discuss in detail how to solve Î˜link(n)â€‹(ğ®(n))superscriptsubscriptÎ˜linkğ‘›superscriptğ®ğ‘›\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}^{(n)}).

IV-A Conjugate Gradient Projection for Solving Î˜link(n)â€‹(ğ®(n))superscriptsubscriptÎ˜linkğ‘›superscriptğ®ğ‘›\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}^{(n)})

We propose an efficient algorithm based on conjugate gradient projection (CGP) to solve (28). CGP utilizes the important and powerful concept of Hessian conjugacy to deflect the gradient direction appropriately so as to achieve the superlinear convergence rate [11], which is similar to that of the well-known quasi-Newton methods (e.g., BFGS method). In each iteration, CGP projects the conjugate gradient direction to find an improving feasible direction. The framework of CGP for solving (28) is shown in AlgorithmÂ 1.

We adopt the â€œArmijoâ€™s Ruleâ€ inexact line search method to avoid excessive objective function evaluations, while still enjoying provable convergence [11]. For convenience, we use Fâ€‹(ğ)ğ¹ğF(\mathbf{Q}) to represent the objective function in (28), where ğ=(ğ1,â€¦,ğK)ğsubscriptğ1â€¦subscriptğğ¾\mathbf{Q}=(\mathbf{Q}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{Q}_{K}) denotes the set of covariance matrices at a node. According to Armijoâ€™s Rule, in the ktâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„k^{th} iteration, we choose Ïƒk=1subscriptğœğ‘˜1\sigma_{k}=1 and Î±k=Î²mksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜superscriptğ›½subscriptğ‘šğ‘˜\alpha_{k}=\beta^{m_{k}} (the same as in [12]), where mksubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜m_{k} is the first non-negative integer mğ‘šm that satisfies

Fâ€‹(ğ(k+1))âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ(k))â‰¥Ïƒâ€‹Î²mâ€‹âŸ¨ğ†(k),ğÂ¯(k)âˆ’ğ(k)âŸ©ğ¹superscriptğğ‘˜1ğ¹superscriptğğ‘˜ğœsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘šsuperscriptğ†ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğğ‘˜superscriptğğ‘˜\displaystyle F(\mathbf{Q}^{(k+1)})-F(\mathbf{Q}^{(k)})\geq\sigma\beta^{m}\langle\mathbf{G}^{(k)},\bar{\mathbf{Q}}^{(k)}-\mathbf{Q}^{(k)}\rangle
=Ïƒâ€‹Î²mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1KTrâ€‹[ğ†iâ€ (k)â€‹(ğÂ¯i(k)âˆ’ği(k))],absentğœsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾Trdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ†ğ‘–â€ absentğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğğ‘–ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\sigma\beta^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{K}\mathrm{Tr}\left[\mathbf{G}_{i}^{{\dagger}(k)}\left(\bar{\mathbf{Q}}_{i}^{(k)}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}^{(k)}\right)\right], (29)

where 0<Î²<10ğ›½10<\beta<1 and 0<Ïƒ<10ğœ10<\sigma<1 are fixed scalars.

Remark 1

It is important to point out that we can exploit the special structure in (IV-B) to significantly reduce the computation complexity in the implementation of the algorithm. Note that the most difficult part in computing ğ†Â¯Ï€â€‹(j)subscriptÂ¯ğ†ğœ‹ğ‘—\bar{\mathbf{G}}_{\pi(j)} is the summation of the terms in the form of ğ‡Ï€â€‹(k)â€ â€‹ğÏ€â€‹(k)â€‹ğ‡Ï€â€‹(k)superscriptsubscriptğ‡ğœ‹ğ‘˜â€ subscriptğğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‡ğœ‹ğ‘˜\mathbf{H}_{\pi(k)}^{{\dagger}}\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(k)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(k)}. Without careful consideration, one may end up computing such additions jâ€‹(2â€‹K+1âˆ’j)/2ğ‘—2ğ¾1ğ‘—2j(2K+1-j)/2 times for ğ†Â¯Ï€â€‹(j)subscriptÂ¯ğ†ğœ‹ğ‘—\bar{\mathbf{G}}_{\pi(j)}. However, notice that when jğ‘—j varies, most of the terms in the summation are still the same. Thus, we can maintain a running sum for ğˆ+âˆ‘k=iKÏÏ€â€‹(k)â€‹ğ‡Ï€â€‹(k)â€ â€‹ğÏ€â€‹(k)â€‹ğ‡Ï€â€‹(k)ğˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¾subscriptğœŒğœ‹ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‡ğœ‹ğ‘˜â€ subscriptğğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‡ğœ‹ğ‘˜\mathbf{I}+\sum_{k=i}^{K}\rho_{\pi(k)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(k)}^{{\dagger}}\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(k)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(k)}, start out from j=Kğ‘—ğ¾j=K, and reduce jğ‘—j by one sequentially. As a result, only one new term is added to the running sum in each iteration, which means we only need to do the addition once in each iteration.

The conjugate gradient direction in the mtâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡â„m^{th} iteration can be computed as ğ†Ï€â€‹(j)(m)=ğ†Â¯Ï€â€‹(i)(m)+Îºmâ€‹ğ†Ï€â€‹(i)(mâˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptğ†ğœ‹ğ‘—ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ†ğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğœ…ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ†ğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘š1\mathbf{G}_{\pi(j)}^{(m)}=\bar{\mathbf{G}}_{\pi(i)}^{(m)}+\kappa_{m}\mathbf{G}_{\pi(i)}^{(m-1)}. We adopt the Fletcher and Reevesâ€™ choice of deflection [11], which can be computed as

Îºm=â€–ğ†Â¯Ï€â€‹(j)(m)â€–2â€–ğ†Â¯Ï€â€‹(j)(mâˆ’1)â€–2.subscriptğœ…ğ‘šsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ†ğœ‹ğ‘—ğ‘š2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ†ğœ‹ğ‘—ğ‘š12\kappa_{m}=\frac{\|\bar{\mathbf{G}}_{\pi(j)}^{(m)}\|^{2}}{\|\bar{\mathbf{G}}_{\pi(j)}^{(m-1)}\|^{2}}. (31)

The purpose of deflecting the gradient using (31) is to find ğ†Ï€â€‹(j)(m)superscriptsubscriptğ†ğœ‹ğ‘—ğ‘š\mathbf{G}_{\pi(j)}^{(m)}, which is the Hessian-conjugate of ğ†Ï€â€‹(j)(mâˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptğ†ğœ‹ğ‘—ğ‘š1\mathbf{G}_{\pi(j)}^{(m-1)}. By doing so, we can eliminate the â€œzigzaggingâ€ phenomenon encountered in the conventional gradient projection method, and achieve the superlinear convergence rate [11] without actually storing a large Hessian approximation matrix as in quasi-Newton methods.

IV-C Projection onto Î©+â€‹(Pmax(n))subscriptÎ©superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›\Omega_{+}(P_{\max}^{(n)})

Noting from (IV-B) that ğ†Ï€â€‹(j)subscriptğ†ğœ‹ğ‘—\mathbf{G}_{\pi(j)} is Hermitian, we have that ğÏ€â€‹(j)(k)â€²=ğÏ€â€‹(j)(k)+skâ€‹ğ†Ï€â€‹(j)(k)\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}^{{}^{\prime}(k)}=\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}^{(k)}+s_{k}\mathbf{G}_{\pi(j)}^{(k)} is Hermitian as well. Then, the projection problem becomes how to simultaneously project |ğ’ªâ€‹(n)|ğ’ªğ‘›|\mathcal{O}\left(n\right)| Hermitian matrices onto the set

Î©+(Pmax(n))â‰œ{ğl|âˆ‘lTrâ€‹{ğl}â‰¤Pmax(n),ğlâª°0,lâˆˆğ’ªâ€‹(n)}.\Omega_{+}(P_{\max}^{(n)})\triangleq\left\{\mathbf{Q}_{l}\left|\begin{array}[]{l}\sum_{l}\mathrm{Tr}\{\mathbf{Q}_{l}\}\leq P_{\max}^{(n)},\\ \mathbf{Q}_{l}\succeq 0,\,\,l\in\mathcal{O}\left(n\right)\end{array}\right.\right\}.

This problem belongs to the class of â€œmatrix nearness problemsâ€ [15, 16], which are not easy to solve in general. However, by exploiting the special structure in Î˜link(n)â€‹(ğ®)superscriptsubscriptÎ˜linkğ‘›ğ®\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}), we are able to design a polynomial-time algorithm.

We construct a block diagonal matrix ğƒ=Diag{ğÏ€â€‹(1)â€‹â€¦â€‹ğÏ€â€‹(K)}âˆˆâ„‚(Kâ‹…nr)Ã—(Kâ‹…nr)ğƒDiag{ğÏ€(1)â€¦ğÏ€(K)}superscriptâ„‚â‹…ğ¾subscriptğ‘›ğ‘Ÿâ‹…ğ¾subscriptğ‘›ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{D}=\mbox{Diag}\mbox{$\left\{\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(1)}\ldots\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(K)}\right\}$}\in\mathbb{C}^{(K\cdot n_{r})\times(K\cdot n_{r})}. It is easy to recognize that ğÏ€â€‹(j)âˆˆÎ©+â€‹(Pmax(n))subscriptğğœ‹ğ‘—subscriptÎ©superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}\in\Omega_{+}(P_{\max}^{(n)}), j=1,â€¦,Kğ‘—1â€¦ğ¾j=1,\ldots,K, only if Trâ€‹(ğƒ)=âˆ‘j=1KTrâ€‹(ğÏ€â€‹(j))â‰¤Pmax(n)Trğƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ¾Trsubscriptğğœ‹ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›\mathrm{Tr}(\mathbf{D})=\sum_{j=1}^{K}\mathrm{Tr}\left(\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}\right)\leq P_{\max}^{(n)} and ğƒâª°0succeeds-or-equalsğƒ0\mathbf{D}\succeq 0. We use Frobenius norm, denoted by âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥F\|\cdot\|_{F}, as the matrix distance criterion. The distance between two matrices ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} and ğğ\mathbf{B} is defined as â€–ğ€âˆ’ğâ€–F=(Trâ€‹[(ğ€âˆ’ğ)â€ â€‹(ğ€âˆ’ğ)])12subscriptnormğ€ğğ¹superscriptTrdelimited-[]superscriptğ€ğâ€ ğ€ğ12\|\mathbf{A}-\mathbf{B}\|_{F}=\left(\mathrm{Tr}\left[(\mathbf{A}-\mathbf{B})^{{\dagger}}(\mathbf{A}-\mathbf{B})\right]\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}. Thus, given a block diagonal matrix ğƒğƒ\mathbf{D}, we wish to find a matrix ğƒ~âˆˆÎ©+â€‹(Pmax(n))~ğƒsubscriptÎ©superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›\tilde{\mathbf{D}}\in\Omega_{+}(P_{\max}^{(n)}) such that ğƒ~~ğƒ\tilde{\mathbf{D}} minimizes â€–ğƒ~âˆ’ğƒâ€–Fsubscriptnorm~ğƒğƒğ¹\|\tilde{\mathbf{D}}-\mathbf{D}\|_{F}. For more convenient algebraic manipulations, we instead study the following equivalent optimization problem:

Minimize12â€‹â€–ğƒ~âˆ’ğƒâ€–F2subject toTrâ€‹(ğƒ~)â‰¤Pmax(n),ğƒ~âª°0.Minimize12superscriptsubscriptnorm~ğƒğƒğ¹2subject toformulae-sequenceTr~ğƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›succeeds-or-equals~ğƒ0\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Minimize}&\frac{1}{2}\|\tilde{\mathbf{D}}-\mathbf{D}\|_{F}^{2}\\ \mbox{subject to}&\mathrm{Tr}(\tilde{\mathbf{D}})\leq P_{\max}^{(n)},\,\,\tilde{\mathbf{D}}\succeq 0.\\ \end{array} (32)

In (32), the objective function is convex in ğƒ~~ğƒ\tilde{\mathbf{D}}, the constraint ğƒ~âª°0succeeds-or-equals~ğƒ0\tilde{\mathbf{D}}\succeq 0 represents the convex cone of positive semidefinite matrices, and the constraint Trâ€‹(ğƒ~)â‰¤Pmax(n)Tr~ğƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›\mathrm{Tr}(\tilde{\mathbf{D}})\leq P_{\max}^{(n)} is a linear constraint. Thus, the problem is a convex minimization problem and we can exactly solve this problem by solving its Lagrangian dual problem. Associating Hermitian matrix ğš·ğš·\mathbf{\Pi} to the constraint ğƒ~âª°0succeeds-or-equals~ğƒ0\tilde{\mathbf{D}}\succeq 0 and Î¼ğœ‡\mu to the constraint Trâ€‹(ğƒ~)â‰¤Pmax(n)Tr~ğƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›\mathrm{Tr}(\tilde{\mathbf{D}})\leq P_{\max}^{(n)}, we can write the Lagrangian as gâ€‹(ğš·,Î¼)=minğƒ~â¡{(1/2)â€‹â€–ğƒ~âˆ’ğƒâ€–F2âˆ’Trâ€‹(ğš·â€ â€‹ğƒ~)+Î¼â€‹(Trâ€‹(ğƒ~)âˆ’Pmax(n))}ğ‘”ğš·ğœ‡subscript~ğƒ12superscriptsubscriptnorm~ğƒğƒğ¹2Trsuperscriptğš·â€ ~ğƒğœ‡Tr~ğƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›g(\mathbf{\Pi},\mu)=\min_{\tilde{\mathbf{D}}}\{(1/2)\|\tilde{\mathbf{D}}-\mathbf{D}\|_{F}^{2}-\mathrm{Tr}(\mathbf{\Pi}^{{\dagger}}\tilde{\mathbf{D}})+\mu(\mathrm{Tr}(\tilde{\mathbf{D}})-P_{\max}^{(n)})\}. Substituting ğƒ~~ğƒ\tilde{\mathbf{D}} back into the Lagrangian, we have

gâ€‹(ğš·,Î¼)=âˆ’12â€‹âˆ¥ğƒâˆ’Î¼â€‹ğˆ+ğš·âˆ¥F2âˆ’Î¼â€‹Pmax(n)+12â€‹â€–ğƒâ€–2.ğ‘”ğš·ğœ‡12superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğƒğœ‡ğˆğš·ğ¹2ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›12superscriptnormğƒ2g(\mathbf{\Pi},\mu)=-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{$\left\lVert\mathbf{D}-\mu\mathbf{I}+\mathbf{\Pi}\right\rVert$}_{F}^{2}-\mu P_{\max}^{(n)}+\frac{1}{2}\|\mathbf{D}\|^{2}.

Therefore, the Lagrangian dual problem can be written as

Maximizeâˆ’12â€‹âˆ¥ğƒâˆ’Î¼â€‹ğˆ+ğš·âˆ¥F2âˆ’Î¼â€‹Pmax(n)+12â€‹â€–ğƒâ€–2subject toğš·âª°0,Î¼â‰¥0.Maximize12superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğƒğœ‡ğˆğš·ğ¹2ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›12superscriptnormğƒ2subject toformulae-sequencesucceeds-or-equalsğš·0ğœ‡0\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Maximize}&-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{$\left\lVert\mathbf{D}-\mu\mathbf{I}+\mathbf{\Pi}\right\rVert$}_{F}^{2}-\mu P_{\max}^{(n)}+\frac{1}{2}\|\mathbf{D}\|^{2}\\ \mbox{subject to}&\mathbf{\Pi}\succeq 0,\mu\geq 0.\end{array} (33)

IV-D Solving the Master Dual Problem

IV-D1 Cutting-Plane Method for Solving Î˜â€‹(ğ®)Î˜ğ®\Theta(\mathbf{u})

The attractive feature of the cutting-plane method is its robustness, speed of convergence, and its simplicity in recovering primal feasible optimal solutions. The primal optimal feasible solution can be exactly computed by averaging all the primal solutions (may or may not be primal feasible) using the dual variables as weights [11]. Letting z=Î˜â€‹(ğ®)ğ‘§Î˜ğ®z=\Theta(\mathbf{u}), the dual problem is equivalent to

Minimizezsubject tozâ‰¥âˆ‘flnâ¡(sf)+âˆ‘lulâ€‹(Rlâ€‹(ğ)âˆ’âŸ¨ğŸ,ğ“Tâ€‹ğlâŸ©)ğ®â‰¥0,Minimizeğ‘§subject toğ‘§subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“subscriptğ‘™subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™ğ1superscriptğ“ğ‘‡subscriptğğ‘™missing-subexpressionğ®0\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Minimize}&z\\ \mbox{subject to}&z\geq\sum_{f}\ln\left(s_{f}\right)+\sum_{l}u_{l}\left(R_{l}(\mathbf{Q})-\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\right)\\ &\mathbf{u}\geq 0,\end{array} (37)

where (ğ’,ğ“,ğ)âˆˆÎ¨ğ’ğ“ğÎ¨(\mathbf{S},\mathbf{T},\mathbf{Q})\in\Psi. Although (37) is a linear program with infinite constraints not known explicitly, we can consider the following approximating problem:

Minimizezsubject tozâ‰¥âˆ‘fln(sf(j))+âˆ‘lul(Rl(ğ(j))âˆ’âŸ¨ğŸ,ğ“(j)â€‹TğlâŸ©)ğ®â‰¥0,\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Minimize}&z\\ \mbox{subject to}&z\geq\sum_{f}\ln(s_{f}^{(j)})+\sum_{l}u_{l}\left(R_{l}(\mathbf{Q}^{(j)})-\right.\\ &\quad\quad\left.\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{(j)T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\right)\!\!\!\\ &\mathbf{u}\geq 0,\end{array} (38)

where the points (ğ’(j),ğ“(j),ğ(j))âˆˆÎ¨superscriptğ’ğ‘—superscriptğ“ğ‘—superscriptğğ‘—Î¨(\mathbf{S}^{(j)},\mathbf{T}^{(j)},\mathbf{Q}^{(j)})\in\Psi, j=1,â€¦,kâˆ’1ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘˜1j=1,\ldots,k-1. The problem in (38) is a linear program with a finite number of constraints and can be solved efficiently. Let (z(k),ğ®(k))superscriptğ‘§ğ‘˜superscriptğ®ğ‘˜(z^{(k)},\mathbf{u}^{(k)}) be an optimal solution to the approximating problem, which we refer to as the master program. If the solution is feasible to (37), then it is an optimal solution to the Lagrangian dual problem. To check the feasibility, we consider the following subproblem:

Maximizeâˆ‘flnâ¡(sf)+âˆ‘lul(k)â€‹(Rlâ€‹(ğ)âˆ’âŸ¨ğŸ,ğ“Tâ€‹ğlâŸ©)subject to(ğ’,ğ“,ğ)âˆˆÎ¨Maximizesubscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“subscriptğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™ğ1superscriptğ“ğ‘‡subscriptğğ‘™subject toğ’ğ“ğÎ¨\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Maximize}&\sum_{f}\ln\left(s_{f}\right)+\sum_{l}u_{l}^{(k)}\left(R_{l}(\mathbf{Q})-\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\right)\\ \mbox{subject to}&(\mathbf{S},\mathbf{T},\mathbf{Q})\in\Psi\end{array} (39)

Suppose that (ğ’(k),ğ“(k),ğ(k))superscriptğ’ğ‘˜superscriptğ“ğ‘˜superscriptğğ‘˜(\mathbf{S}^{(k)},\mathbf{T}^{(k)},\mathbf{Q}^{(k)}) is an optimal solution to the subproblem (39) and Î˜âˆ—â€‹(ğ®(k))superscriptÎ˜superscriptğ®ğ‘˜\Theta^{*}(\mathbf{u}^{(k)}) is the corresponding optimal objective value. If zkâ‰¥Î˜âˆ—â€‹(ğ®(k))subscriptğ‘§ğ‘˜superscriptÎ˜superscriptğ®ğ‘˜z_{k}\geq\Theta^{*}(\mathbf{u}^{(k)}), then ğ®(k)superscriptğ®ğ‘˜\mathbf{u}^{(k)} is an optimal solution to the Lagrangian dual problem. Otherwise, for ğ®=ğ®(k)ğ®superscriptğ®ğ‘˜\mathbf{u}=\mathbf{u}^{(k)}, the inequality constraint in (37) is not satisfied for (ğ’(j),ğ“(j),ğ(j))superscriptğ’ğ‘—superscriptğ“ğ‘—superscriptğğ‘—(\mathbf{S}^{(j)},\mathbf{T}^{(j)},\mathbf{Q}^{(j)}). Thus, we can add the constraint

zâ‰¥âˆ‘flnâ¡(sf(k))+âˆ‘lulâ€‹(Rlâ€‹(ğ(k))âˆ’âŸ¨ğŸ,ğ“(k)â€‹Tâ€‹ğlâŸ©)ğ‘§subscriptğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘™subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™superscriptğğ‘˜1superscriptğ“ğ‘˜ğ‘‡subscriptğğ‘™z\geq\sum_{f}\ln\left(s_{f}^{(k)}\right)+\sum_{l}u_{l}\left(R_{l}(\mathbf{Q}^{(k)})-\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{(k)T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\right) (40)

to (38), and re-solve the master linear program. Obviously, (z(k),ğ®(k))superscriptğ‘§ğ‘˜superscriptğ®ğ‘˜(z^{(k)},\mathbf{u}^{(k)}) violates (40) and will be cut off by (40). The cutting plane algorithm is summarized in AlgorithmÂ 3.

IV-D2 Subgradient Algorithm for Solving Î˜â€‹(ğ®)Î˜ğ®\Theta(\mathbf{u})

Since the Lagrangian dual objective function is piece-wise differentiable, subgradient method can also be applied. For Î˜â€‹(ğ®)Î˜ğ®\Theta(\mathbf{u}), starting with an initial ğ®(1)superscriptğ®1\mathbf{u}^{(1)} and after evaluating subproblems Î˜netâ€‹(ğ®)subscriptÎ˜netğ®\Theta_{\mathrm{net}}(\mathbf{u}) and Î˜linksubscriptÎ˜link\Theta_{\mathrm{link}} for ğ®(k)superscriptğ®ğ‘˜\mathbf{u}^{(k)} in the ktâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„k^{th} iteration, we update the dual variables by ğ®(k+1)=[ğ®kâˆ’Î»(k)â€‹ğ(k)]+superscriptğ®ğ‘˜1subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptğ®ğ‘˜subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜superscriptğğ‘˜\mathbf{u}^{(k+1)}=\left[\mathbf{u}^{k}-\lambda_{(k)}\mathbf{d}^{(k)}\right]_{+}, where the operator [â‹…]+subscriptdelimited-[]â‹…[\cdot]_{+} projects a vector on to the nonnegative orthant, and Î»ksubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜\lambda_{k} denotes a positive scalar step size. ğ(k)superscriptğğ‘˜\mathbf{d}^{(k)} is a subgradient of the Lagrangian at point ğ®(k)superscriptğ®ğ‘˜\mathbf{u}^{(k)}. It is proved in [11] that the subgradient algorithm converges if the step size Î»ksubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜\lambda_{k} satisfies Î»kâ†’0â†’subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜0\lambda_{k}\rightarrow 0 as kâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘˜k\rightarrow\infty and âˆ‘k=0âˆÎ»k=âˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\lambda_{k}=\infty. A simple and useful step size selection strategy is the divergent harmonic series âˆ‘k=1âˆÎ²â€‹1k=âˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ›½1ğ‘˜\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\beta\frac{1}{k}=\infty, where Î²ğ›½\beta is a constant. The subgradient for the Lagrangian dual problem can be computed as

Rlâ€‹(ğâˆ—â€‹(ğ®))âˆ’âŸ¨ğŸ,ğ“âˆ—â€‹(ğ®)Tâ€‹ğlâŸ©,l=1,2,â€¦,L.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘…ğ‘™superscriptğğ®1superscriptğ“superscriptğ®ğ‘‡subscriptğğ‘™ğ‘™12â€¦ğ¿R_{l}(\mathbf{Q}^{*}(\mathbf{u}))-\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{*}(\mathbf{u})^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle,\quad l=1,2,\ldots,L. (41)

Specifically, the subgradient method has the following properties which make it possible to be implemented in a distributed fashion:

  1. 1.

    Subgradient computation only requires local traffic information âŸ¨ğŸ,ğ“Tâ€‹ğlâŸ©1superscriptğ“ğ‘‡subscriptğğ‘™\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle and the available link capacity information Rlâ€‹(ğ)subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™ğR_{l}(\mathbf{Q}) at each link lğ‘™l. As a result, it can be computed locally.

  2. 2.

    The choice of step size Î»k=Î²â€‹1ksubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜ğ›½1ğ‘˜\lambda_{k}=\beta\frac{1}{k} depends only upon the iteration index kğ‘˜k, and does not require any other global knowledge. In conjunction with the first property, the dual variable, in the iterative form of ul(k+1)=ul(k)+Î»kâ€‹(âˆ‚Î˜â€‹(ğ®)/âˆ‚ul)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘˜subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜Î˜ğ®subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™u_{l}^{(k+1)}=u_{l}^{(k)}+\lambda_{k}(\partial\Theta(\mathbf{u})/\partial u_{l}), can also be computed locally.

  3. 3.

    The objective functions Î˜linksubscriptÎ˜link\Theta_{\mathrm{link}} can be decomposed on a node-by-node basis such that each node in the network can perform the computation in parallel. Likewise, the network layer subproblem Î˜netsubscriptÎ˜net\Theta_{\mathrm{net}} can be decomposed on a source-by-source basis such that each source node can perform the routing computation locally after receiving the dual variable information of each link in the network.

It is worth to point out that care must be taken when recovering the primal feasible optimal solution in the subgradient method. Generally, the primal variables in the dual optimal solution are not primal feasible unless the dual optimal solution happens to be the saddle point. Fortunately, since CRPA-E is convex, its primal feasible optimal solution can be exactly computed by solving a linear programming problem (see [11] for further details). However, such a recovery approach cannot be implemented in a distributed fashion. In this paper, we adopt a variant of Shorâ€™s rule to recovery primal optimal feasible solution. Due to space limitation, we refer readers to [18] for more details.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we present some numerical results through simulations to provide further insights on solving CRPA. Nğ‘N randomly-generated MIMO-enabled nodes are uniformly distributed in a square region. Each node in the network is equipped with two antennas. The maximum transmit power for each node is set to Pmax=10subscriptğ‘ƒ10P_{\max}=10dBm. Each node in the network is assigned a unit bandwidth. We illustrate a 15-node network example, as shown in Fig.Â 5, to show the convergence process of the cutting-plane and the subgradient methods for solving ğƒCRPAâˆ’EsuperscriptğƒCRPAE\mathbf{D}^{\mathrm{CRPA-E}}. In this example, there are three flows transmitting across the network: N14 to N1, N6 to N10, and N5 to N4, respectively.

V-A Cutting-Plane Method

For the 15-node example in Fig.Â 5, the convergence process for the cutting-plane method is illustrated in Fig.Â 6.

The optimal objective value for this 15-node example is 6.72. The optimal flows for sessions N14 to N1, N6 to N10, and N5 to N4 are 9.179.179.17 bps/Hz, 9.309.309.30 bps/Hz, and 9.939.939.93 bps/Hz, respectively. It can be observed that the cutting-plane algorithm is very efficient: It converges with approximately 160 cuts. As expected, the duality gap is zero because the convexity of the transformed equivalent problem based on dual MIMO-MAC.

V-B Subgradient Method

For the 15-node example in Fig.Â 5, the convergence process for the subgradient method is illustrated in Fig.Â 7.

The step size selection is Î»k=0.1/ksubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜0.1ğ‘˜\lambda_{k}=0.1/k. The subgradient method also achieves the same optimal solution and objective value when it converges. However, it is seen that the subgradient algorithm takes approximately 1600 iterations to converge, which is much slower than the cutting-plane method. This is partially due to the heuristic nature in step size selection (cannot be too large or too small at each step). It is also partially due to the cumbersomeness in recovering the primal feasible solution in the subgradient method. In this example, the dual upper bound takes approximately 1050 iterations to reach near the optimal. However, the near-optimal primal feasible solution cannot be identified until after 1500 iterations.

V-C Comparison between BC and TDM

We now study how much performance gain we can get by using Gaussian vector broadcast channel technique as opposed to the conventional time-division (TDM) scheme. The cross-layer optimization problem of MIMO-based mesh networks over TDM scheme is also a convex problem. Thus, the basic Lagrangian dual decomposition framework and gradient projection technique for the link layer subproblem are still applicable. The only difference is in the gradient computation, which is simpler in TDM case. For the same 15-node network with TDM, we plot the convergence process of the cutting-plane algorithm in Fig.Â 8.

In TDM case, the optimal objective value is 5.01. For this example, we have 34.4%percent34.434.4\% improvement by using DPC.

VI Related Work

Despite significant research progress in using MIMO for single-user communications, research on multi-user multi-hop MIMO networks is still in its inception stage. There are many open problems, and many areas are still poorly understood [19]. Currently, the relatively well-studied research area of multi-user MIMO systems are cellular systems, which are single-hop and infrastructure-based. For multi-hop MIMO-based mesh networks, research results remain limited. In [20], Hu and Zhang studied the problem of joint medium access control and routing, with a consideration of optimal hop distance to minimize end-to-end delay. In [21], Sundaresan and Sivakumar used simulations to study various characteristics and tradeoffs (multiplexing gain vs. diversity gain) of MIMO links that can be leveraged by routing layer protocols in rich multipath environments to improve performance. In [22], Lee et al. proposed a distributed algorithm for MIMO-based multi-hop ad hoc networks, in which diversity and multiplexing gains of each link are controlled to achieve the optimal rate-reliability tradeoff. The optimization problem assumes fixed SINRs and fixed routes between source and destination nodes. However, in these works, there is no explicit consideration of per-antenna power allocation and their impact on upper layers. Moreover, DPC in cross-layer design has never been studied either.

VII Conclusions

In this paper, we investigated the cross-layer optimization of DPC per-antenna power allocation and multi-hop multi-path routing for MIMO-based wireless mesh networks. Our contributions are three-fold. First, this paper is the first work that studies the impacts of applying dirty paper coding, which is the optimal transmission scheme for MIMO broadcast channels (MIMO-BC), to the cross-layer design for MIMO-based wireless mesh networks. We showed that the network performance has dramatic improvements compared to that of the conventional time-division/frequency division schemes. Second, we solved the challenging non-connvex cross-layer optimization problem by exploiting the channel duality between MIMO-MAC and MIMO-BC, and we showed that transformed problem under dual MIMO-MAC is convex. We simplified the maximum weighted sum rate problem, thus paving the way for solving the link layer subproblem in the Lagrangian dual decomposition. Last, for the transformed problem, we develop an efficient solution procedure that integrates Lagrangian dual decomposition, conjugate gradient projection based on matrix differential calculus, cutting-plane, and subgradient methods. Our results substantiate the importance of cross-layer optimization for MIMO-based wireless mesh networks with Gaussian vector broadcast channels.
